Posts.Content: Every 6 months is a good spot to be in. It gives you time to forget about this nasty disease for awhile. GOOD LUCK and may your psa be a thing of the past!
Posts.Signature: DOB 6/59 48yrs. Dec. 2007 psa went from 1.9 to 2.6 Biopsy Jan. 2008 2 of 8 cores positive Feb. of 2008 had Da Vinci prostatectomy. Final pathology 3+4=7,T2C, tumor size 30% Organ confined 85%, Capsular penetration neg. Surgical margins 85% a little shaky up near bladder. Seminal vessels neg. First psa 1 month after surgery 3/08 was .109 6/08 .118 10/08 0.1 1/09 0.2 4/09 0.1 9/09 thru 12/12 was 0.2 It then jumped to 0.4 1 week before SRT began psa dropped to 0.3 40 sessions SRT completed in first week of April 2013 psa post SRT July 2013 0.1 10/13 0.1 1/2014 <0.1 First time since this all started 6 yrs. ago undetectable. What a great feeling. 5/14 <0.1 9/14 <0.1 3/15 <0.1 10/15 <0.1 09/16 <0.1 03/17 <0.1 12/17 <0.1 12/18 <0.1

Posts.Title: For many months this site was a source of support and comfort during my

Posts.Content: Hi Tilly , sorry that you and your partner are here with us. However the wealth of information you can get by being here will be valuable as you and your partner start your journey. Getting Walsh's book is a great suggestion by Highlander. Having a higher Gleason score does not mean for sure that the cancer has spread outside the prostate. As for treatment options, it is correct that age is a factor. Also the biopsy, health, and stage of the cancer, and most important what you and your partner decide. GOOD LUCK

Posts.Content: Sorry, your with us Wayno2 but welcome. Reading what you typed you sound just like I was when you first find out, that you have pc, it rattles your cage. There is so much information to digest you feel like your head is going to explode. I was 48 when I was told I had pc. After the initial shock, decided with my doctor, that I"ve got to much life to live,so lets put this behind us. Everyone has given you good advice so far on the pros and cons of surgery vs radiation. It looks to me that you may have answered your questions yourself with the final paragraph in your thread. You talk about the cancer being in its early stage and organ confined. All of us will agree that now is the best time to hit the cancer and hit it hard. It sounds like surgery might be a good choice. Highlander talks about the BPH factor and Ray61 mentions the biopsy factor. Surgery allows a pathologist to examine the prostate and give you a complete report. Whatever you decide GOOD LUCK and we'll be her for you.

Posts.Title: No one on same page...frustrating!

Posts.Content: Sorry, your with us Wayno2 but welcome. Reading what you typed you sound just like I was when you first find out, that you have pc, it rattles your cage. There is so much information to digest you feel like your head is going to explode. I was 48 when I was told I had pc. After the initial shock, decided with my doctor, that I"ve got to much life to live,so lets put this behind us. Everyone has given you good advice so far on the pros and cons of surgery vs radiation. It looks to me that you may have answered your questions yourself with the final paragraph in your thread. You talk about the cancer being in its early stage and organ confined. All of us will agree that now is the best time to hit the cancer and hit it hard. It sounds like surgery might be a good choice. Highlander talks about the BPH factor and Ray61 mentions the biopsy factor. Surgery allows a pathologist to examine the prostate and give you a complete report. Whatever you decide GOOD LUCK and we'll be her for you.

Posts.Title: Why dont we all stop saying "sorry you have to join our club"

Posts.Content: First I want to thank all of you who contribute to this site and the calming effect it has had on me. This is my first post. I have been checking in on the forum since about December of 2014. In Dec. 2007 my psa went from 1.9 to 2.6. As a precaution my urologist thought a biopsy was in order , due to the fact the year previously a rectal exam told him there was a small change to the right lobe. Had the biopsy in Jan. of 08 and 2 of 8 cores came back positive. Happy Holidays to me. I was only 48 so I told him cut it out and lets get rid of it. He agreed for my age it was the best course of action. So, the next month Feb. 08 had the robotic prostatectomy. Final pathology 3+4=7 T2C 30% involvement only took one set of nerves, seminal vessels neg., surgical margins 85% neg. a little concern up near bladder. organ confined 85% neg. capsular penetration neg. First psa after surgery in March of 2008 was .109 , 6/08 .118, 10/08 0.1, 1/09 0.2, 4/09 0.1, 9/09 0.2 Every test after Sept. of 09 until December of 2012 was 0.2 This is the point where I got nervous. Most of you and the literature say that a biochemical reoccurrence has happened when you have two consecutive psa tests of 0.2 or higher. My urologist uses 0.3. So after 4 1/2 years of my psa being 0.2 or lower, it jumped to 0.4 in December of 2012. My urologist didn't hesitate and sent me to a cancer radiologist. She set up 40 sessions of srt and we did one last psa test before starting. It was 0.3 My 40 sessions of srt ended the first week of April of 2013. Treatments went real well I even won the NCAA mens basketball pool that they let me get in on. I bought all those good people pizza with the winnings. Not enough is said about the good people that do that work day in and out. God Bless you all. Well, my first psa after srt was in July of 2013 and it was 0.1 My urologist was happy. Next test was January of 2014 it was less than 0.1 my first undetectable ever, what a great feeling. Next was 5/14 less than 0.1, 10/14 less than 0.1 My next test is in April of 2015. Well that's the end of my adventure so far. Right now its better than it has been since Dec. of 2008. So once again thanks for all of you who write these posts. I am sure that there are many out here reading these posts to get info and encouragement, keep it up it really helps on those bad days.
Posts.Title: Thanks for the peace of mind R.L.T.

Posts.Content: It really depends on what you and your doctor decide. Ask him or her about similar cases like yours, and what were the results with those. Remember you are your own best advocate on what you feel is the right thing to do. Read all you can talk to people that have gone through it already, but make sure what you decide with your doctor and family, that you will have peace of mind about your decision down the road. GOOD LUCK !

Posts.Title: Mets to lymph nodes

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear read about your situation Gunny. You and I are pretty similar in case histories, I was 48 when DX and had T2c disease also. I made it 56 months at 0.2 or less before jumping to 0.4. Went ahead and had the salvage radiation, and am now back to <0.1 for a year and a half now. So keep your chin up because there is still a good chance that the radiation will kill whats left of that damn cancer and you will be fine. I am living proof. GOOD LUCK !

Posts.Title: Prostrate Cancer 2 years after surgery and radiation

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear read about your situation Gunny. You and I are pretty similar in case histories, I was 48 when DX and had T2c disease also. I made it 56 months at 0.2 or less before jumping to 0.4. Went ahead and had the salvage radiation, and am now back to <0.1 for a year and a half now. So keep your chin up because there is still a good chance that the radiation will kill whats left of that damn cancer and you will be fine. I am living proof. GOOD LUCK !

Posts.Title: Here we go again...

Posts.Content: Just came across your post. There is know doubt in my mind that the advice you have gotten already is good advice. You are a young man and have many years ahead of you. Get the best treatment you can and move on with your life. When you look back on it in a couple of years, when its all said and done you will be so glad you did not hesitate. You don't want those second thoughts to creep in. Trust me I may have hesitated, and there is nothing worse than thinking , should I have pulled the trigger sooner! Good Luck with your choice.

Posts.Content: Hi Mary, I also agree with Chuck and Ray. 57 is so young, I would not delay on treatment. If it is nearing the prostate wall, dealing with it sooner rather than later is the choice I would make and did in my case. I am also a firm believer that surgery at a young age is the way to go. Get rid of it and go on and enjoy life. Also if there ever was a rise in the psa, radiation will still give you a chance to kill it. Keep us posted and GOOD LUCK

Posts.Content: Hi Terrified, I agree totally with what Chuck is telling you. Maybe holding off until he has a detectable psa may be a option. Please check with his doctor. I can only speak from my own experience. After my surgery I had a psa of 0.2 for 3 and a half years before it climbed to 0.4, that's when my doctor said it was time for radiation. I now have been at <0.1 for over a year now. Remember know two prostate cancer cases are the same. You, your dad, his doctor, and family must decide what is right for him. GOOD LUCK
